results.headline: Review: ‘The Forest’ Centers on the Search for a Twin at a Suicide Site in Japan
results.summary_short: Natalie Dormer plays twins, one of whom has gone missing, in this horror film by Jason Zada, set in an area near Mount Fuji where many have taken their own lives.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Forest

results.headline: Review: In ‘Sweaty Betty,’ Two Single Dads and Their Pals Getting Through the Day
results.summary_short: Joseph Frank and Zachary Reed’s first feature follows two young men, a 1,000-pound pig and a lively pit bull as they weave in and out of their neighborhood outside Washington.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sweaty Betty

results.headline: Review: In ‘The Himalayas,’ Two Climbers Form an Indelible Bond
results.summary_short: In this adventure film, an experienced climber and his protégé form a lifelong bond when they reach the world’s third highest peak together.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Himalayas

results.headline: Review: ‘Only Yesterday,’ Isao Takahata’s Time-Jumping Anime
results.summary_short: Mr. Takahata’s 1991 feature about a woman and her younger self gets a new voice cast (including Daisy Ridley) for its release in the United States.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Only Yesterday

results.headline: Review: In ‘Yosemite,’ a Coming-of-Age Tale of 3 Boys in 1980s California
results.summary_short: Gabrielle Demeestere’s debut feature is adapted in part from stories by James Franco, who is a co-star in the movie.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Yosemite

results.headline: Review: In ‘Other People’s Children,’ a Woman’s Pain and Search for Artistic Solace
results.summary_short: A self-destructive filmmaker walks cluelessly toward her own undoing as she tries to make a documentary about people who live on the streets.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Other People's Children

results.headline: Review: ‘Anomalisa’ Pairs Charlie Kaufman and Lonely Puppets
results.summary_short: The film follows a melancholy man who is living in a banal world.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Anomalisa

results.headline: Review: ‘Point Break,’ an X-Games Remake
results.summary_short: Luke Bracey and Édgar Ramírez follow in the footsteps of Keanu Reeves and Patrick Swayze in the updated version of Kathryn Bigelow’s 1991 classic.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Point Break

results.display_title: The Story of the Last Chrysanthemums
results.headline: Review: Restored ‘The Story of the Last Chrysanthemum’ Reveals Director’s Artistry and Empathy
results.summary_short: Kenji Mizoguchi’s 1939 film is a desperately sad story told with utter and potentially unsettling conviction.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Story of the Last Chrysanthemums

results.headline: Review: Quentin Tarantino’s ‘The Hateful Eight’ Blends Verbiage and Violence
results.summary_short: Mr. Tarantino’s western tale of vengeance settles outlaws and bounty hunters around the fire to chat — until it’s time to start killing one another.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Hateful Eight

results.headline: Review: ‘TransFatty Lives’ Chronicles a Life With Lou Gehrig’s Disease
results.summary_short: A young D.J. and video-maker follows his struggles after a life-altering diagnosis.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of TransFatty Lives

results.headline: Review: ‘The Revenant’ Welcomes You to Paradise. Now Prepare to Fall.
results.summary_short: The film, directed by Alejandro G. Iñárritu and starring Leonardo DiCaprio, is based on true, terrible events in the early American West.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Revenant

results.headline: Review: Jennifer Lawrence as a Modern-Day Cinderella in ‘Joy’
results.summary_short: In David O. Russell’s film, Ms. Lawrence plays a would-be entrepreneur surrounded by family members ogreish enough for a fairy tale.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Joy

results.headline: Review: In ‘Concussion,’ a Doctor’s Cri de Coeur Against Football’s Risks
results.summary_short: Will Smith plays Bennet Omalu, whose findings in an autopsy of a former pro-football player led to an epic clash with the N.F.L.

results.headline: Review: ‘Daddy’s Home’ Stars Mark Wahlberg and Will Ferrell, Playing Naughty and Nice
results.summary_short: A contentedly married man’s relationship with his stepchildren comes under siege when the children’s biological father comes back into their lives.

results.headline: Review: ‘Mr. Six’ Is a Guan Hu Character Study
results.summary_short: In this film, a former bad guy in Beijing has to figure out how to rescue his kidnapped son.

results.headline: Review: ‘Where to Invade Next,’ Michael Moore’s Latest Documentary
results.summary_short: Mr. Moore travels through Europe in search of solutions to what he considers to be America’s social ills.

results.headline: Review: In ‘45 Years,’ a Dead Flame Threatens a Marriage
results.summary_short: Charlotte Rampling and Tom Courtenay play a couple whose union is unexpectedly complicated by the discovery of the husband’s long-dead former girlfriend in a glacier.

results.headline: Review: In ‘He Never Died,’ Mastering Longevity if Not Social Skills
results.summary_short: Henry Rollins plays Jack, who has spent centuries perfecting the art of being nondescript, in this enjoyably strange horror film.

results.headline: Review: ‘The Genital Warriors’ Revisits Bygone Romances
results.summary_short: Magic wands, mental wards and rivals who loved the same man figure in this film directed by Matthew O.L. Way.
